Name: INDENO(1,2,3-CD)PYRENE
Description: Indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene is a member of pyrenes.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Sims RC, Overcash MR; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983) (2) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (3) Wang Z et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 1336-41 (2009) (4) Ratola N et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 5 631-47 (2010) (5) Wan Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3109-14 (2007) (6) Chovanec A et al; Chemosphere 29: 2117-33 (1994) (7) Galuszka A; Chemosphere 67: 1415-22 (2007) (8) Krommer V et al; Chemosphere 67: 1956-66 (2007)
plant_concentrations.Value: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in respective young and old leaves of beech at 38 and 234 ug/kg, oak at 26 and 150 ug/kg and tobacco at 18 and 38 ug/kg(1). Casuarina littorina (needles) collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia did not contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene; leaf litter collected from the same area contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 45 ng/g wet weight(2). In April 2005, pine needle samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 2-9 ng/g dry weight(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in pine needle samples from 27 locations scattered all over the Portuguese continental territory at 0.7-7.9 and 0.6-9.5 ng/g dry weight in 19 Pinus pinea and 12 Pinus pinaster samples, respectively; samples were collected in April 2007(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in phytoplankton/seston from Bohai Bay, north China at 7.02 ng/g dry weight in samples collected May, June and Sept 2002(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in aquatic moss samples collected from the Danube and Traun rivers in Austria at 19-22 and 9.5-10 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 8-68 and <5-29 ng/g dry weight in moss species H. splendens and P. schreberi, respectively; samples were collected July 2005 from 10 locations in the southern part of the Holy Cross Mountains, Poland(7). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in moss samples from nine sites at 8.2-64 ng/g dry weight with a mean of 10.8 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected Sept 2005 from Wienerwald, Austria(8).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Jones KC et al; Sci Tot Environ 78: 117-30 (1989)
plant_concentrations.Value: Since the 1840s, crops have been harvested and stored for long-term agricultural studies at a site in the UK. Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene levels in grass samples were as follows(1):

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Zhao Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5853-9 (2006)
plant_concentrations.Value: In August 2003, bark from 15 species of trees of different lipid content and surface area were sampled and the pseudo bark air partition coefficient (Kba) was calculated for indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Broman D et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 9: 429-42 (1990) (2) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (3) Wan Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3109-14 (2007) (4) Cailleaud K et al; Chemosphere 70: 270-80 (2007) (5) Perugini M et al; J Agri Food Chem 57: 7440-4 (2009)
animal_concentrations.Value: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in the gallbladders of common eider (Somateria mollissima) at a mean concentration of 1.5 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected in the northern Baltic coastal areas of Sweden Sept 1985 to Oct 1986(1). Slugs, beetles (Platyzosteria nitida and Laxta granicollis), millipedes and earthworms collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 1, 1-2, 1 and 6 ng/g wet weight indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene, respectively(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in herring gull (Larus argentatus) collected from Bohai Bay, China November 2002 at 16.83 ng/g dry weight(3). Zooplankton (Eurytemora affinis) from the Seine Estuary (France) contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at not detected to 263 ng/L in samples collected Nov 2002 to Feb 2005(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected (detection limit 0.21 ng/g wet weight) in drone honey bees (Apis mellifera) collected May-Oct 2007 from eight sample locations (unpolluted, moderately polluted, polluted) in Italy(5).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Maccubbin AE et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 876-82 (1985) (2) Malins DC et al; Carcinogenesis 6: 1463-9 (1985) (3) Rao VR et al; Ecotoxicol Environ Safety 33: 44-54 (1996) (4) El Deeb KZ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 373-9 (2007) (5) Perugini M et al; Chemosphere 66: 1904-10 (2007) (6) Malik A et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 80: 134-8 (2008)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in the stomach contents of white suckers (Catastomus commersoni) at one of three locations of Lake Erie at 14.95 ng/g(1). Composite stomach organisms, liver and muscle of English sole (Parophrys vetulus) collected from Eagle Harbor, WA contained respective average concentrations of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 1200-1600, <10 and <2.4 ng/g dry weight(2). Composite stomach and liver samples of English sole (Parophrys vetulus) from President Point, WA contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 13 and <29 ng/g dry weight, respectively(2). Average indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations in benthic macroinvertebrates, crayfish (Astacidae), redbreast sunfish (Lepomis auritus) and stonerollers (Campostoma anomalum) collected from East Fork Poplar Creek in Oak Ridge, TN were 2.00, 10.14, 0.95 and 20.30 ug/kg, respectively(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in muscle of bottom feeding fish (Solea solea) and bivalve (Donax trunculus), but was detected in shrimp (Peneaus japonicus) and bottom feeding fish (Diplodus vulgaris) at respective concentrations of 2.2 and 157.01 ng/g wet weight; samples were collected Feb 2004 from Abu Qir Bay, Egypt(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected (detection limit 0.25 ug/kg) in Norway lobster (Nephrops norvegicus), red mullet (Mullus barbatus), European flying squid (Todarodes sagittatus), Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus), blue whiting (Micromesistius potassou), European hake (Merluccius merluccius) or Mediterranean mussels (Mitylus galloprovincialis); organisms were collected from Central Adriatic Sea, Italy in July and December 2004(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in edible fish samples collected 2004 to 2005 from three sites on the Gomti River, India(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Environ Res 9: 193-209 (1983) (2) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Pollut Bull 14: 94-7 (1983) (3) Marcus JM, Stokes TP; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 35: 835-44 (1985) (4) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 172-80 (1996) (5) Pereira WE et al; Mar Pollut Bull 24: 103-109 (1992) (6) Foster GD, Wright DA; Mar Pollut Bull 19: 459-65 (1988)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Mussels (Mytilus edulis) from Yaquina Bay, OR contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 1.0-9.4 ug/kg wet weight (site proximal to industry) and 0.2-0.5 ug/kg wet weight at a remote site; samples were collected 1979-1980(1). Softshell clams (Mya arenaria) collected June 1976 to August 1979 from a remote site and a site proximal to industry in Coos Bay, Oregon contained 4.3-7.5 and 1.3-8.7 ppb of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene, respectively(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in oysters (Crassostrea virginica) collected spring (March 29 to April 14) or summer (July 26 to Aug 11) of 1983 from Palmetto Bay or Fripp Island marinas, SC; it was detected at 1.7 ug/kg in the summer at in oysters collected from a Outdoor Resorts Marina, SC(3). Clams (Corbicula fluminea) collected in 1992 from Orestimba Creek, Dry Creek, Mokelumne River and Stanislaus River contained <0.5-14 ng/g of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene(4). Asian clams (Potamocorbula amurensis) collected from eight sites of Suisun Bay, CA contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at not detected to 59 ng/g dry weight(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in Baltic clams (Macoma balthica) or clam worms (Nereis succinea) collected from Chesapeake Bay habitats(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Bjoerseth A et al; Sci Total Environ 13: 71-86 (1979) (2) Broman D et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 9: 429-42 (1990) (3) Maher WA, Aislabie J; Sci Total Environ 112: 143-64 (1992) (4) Naes K et al; Sci Total Environ 163: 93-106 (1995) (5) Namiesnik J et al; Chemosphere 73: 938-44 (2008) (6) Nakata H et al; Ecotoxicol Environ Saf 99: 61-8 (2014)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in mussels (Modiolus modiolus, Mytilus edulis) at 209-6218 ppb dry weight; samples were collected from Saudafjord in Norway(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in seston and the soft parts of blue mussels (Mytilus edulis) at 160 and 13 ng/g dry weight, respectively; samples were collected in the northern Baltic coastal areas of Sweden Sept 1985 to Oct 1986(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in coral rock oysters from Mermaid Sound in Australian waters at <0.01-5 ug/kg wet weight(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in periwinkle (Littorina littorea) from Lista and in blue mussel (Mytilus edulis) from Vefsnfjord collected in 1991 Norway in the vicinity of aluminum smelters outfall at 137 and 4 ug/kg wet weight, respectively(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected (detection limit 1.3 ug/kg dry weight) in mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis) from non-polluted and polluted areas of Mokpo Bay, Korea; samples were collected April 10, 2004(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in bivalves collected July to Oct 2008 from 18 locations in Yatsushiro Sea, Japan at 0.06-6.6 ng/g wet weight(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Uthe JF, Musial CJ; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 730-8 (1986)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: The concentration of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene in lobster (Homarus americanus) following 3 months exposure to creosoted timbers and transfer to clean water for 13 days was 390-4300 and 12-170 ng/g wet weight in the digestive gland and tail muscle, respectively. Lobsters harvested 1982 and 1984 from the south arm of Sydney Bay and from Port Morien, Nova Scotia, Canada and lobsters harvested from Sydney Harbor in 1984 then transferred to laboratory conditions for 12 months had the following indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations(1):

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Johnson AC et al; Marine Environ Res 15: 1-16 (1985) (2) Fabacher DL et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 7: 529-43 (1988) (3) Great Lakes Water Quality Board; Report to the International Joint Commission Vol II, Appendix B (1989) (4) Marcus JM, Stokes TP; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 35: 835-44 (1985) (5) Kauss PB, Hamdy YS; Hydrobiologia 219:37-62 (1991) (6) Baker JE et al; Environ Sci Technol 25: 500-9 (1991) (7) Huntley SL et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 51: 865-72 (1993) (8) Echols KR et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 55: 161-72 (2008) (9) Khalil MF, Ghosh U; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5681-7 (2006) (10) Hawthorne SB et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 25: 2901-11 (2006) (11) Debruyn JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 3467-73 (2009) (12) Huang L et al; Sci Total Environ 487: 173-86 (2014)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 49 sediment samples collected June and July 1982 from Penobscot Bay, ME at 9-228 ppb dry weight(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was identified in sediment extracts at 6.40, 1.40 and 0.18 ug/g dry sediment from the Black, Cuyahoga and Menominee rivers in the Great Lakes, respectively(2). Sediment samples collected from the Detroit River in 1982 contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 0.16-10.72 mg/kg; 13 of 31 samples were positive(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations were <1.3-176.9 ug/kg in sediment samples collected 1983 from Palmetto Bay, Outdoor Resorts and Fripp Island marinas South Carolina(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was found in surficial sediments from the St. Mary's River, MI in 1985 at <0.02-5.30 mg/kg dry weight(5). Surficial sediment and surface water suspended solids sampled from Lake Superior contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at mean concentrations of 279.4 and 43 ng/g, respectively(6). Mean indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations in sediments from Arthur Kill, Hackensack River, Kill Van Kull, Passaic River and Newark Bay, NJ were 0.74, 1.0, 0.53, 1.8 and 3.0 mg/kg dry weight, respectively; samples were collected Nov 1991 to March 1993(7). In 18 sediment samples collected Oct 28 to Nov 6, 2002 from 19 locations on the lower Missouri River, indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 6.4-171 ng/g dry weight(8). Seven sediment samples collected in the vicinity of a former manufactured gas plant on the Hudson River, NY contained 4.8-45.5 mg/kg of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene; samples were collected in 2003(9). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations were not detected to 314 ug/g in sediment samples from 112 sites from 8 historically contaminated locations in New York and North Carolina; samples were collected 2003 to 2005(10). Pore water concentrations of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene from 34 of these samples were not detected to 0.16 ng/g(10). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 1 of 7 sediment samples collected Aug 2005 from Lake Erie at 0.81 mg/kg(11). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 5.9-74.1 ng/g dry weight in 24 samples collected Aug 16-19, 2011 from the southern part of Lake Michigan(12).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Merrill EG, Wade TL; Environ Sci Technol 19: 597-603 (1985) (2) Malins DC et al; Carcinogenesis 6: 1463-9 (1985) (3) Prahl FG, Carpenter R; Est Coast Shelf Sci 18: 703-19 (1984) (4) Pereira WE et al; Mar Environ Res 41: 299-314 (1996) (5) Pereira WE et al; Mar Pollut Bull 24: 103-9 (1992)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected, not quantified, in sediments from the Elizabeth River in Virginia(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in sediments collected Nov 1983 to April 1984 from Eagle Harbor in Puget Sound and President Point, WA at 120-1200 and 30 ng/g dry weight, respectively(2). Sediment cores collected from 17 locations on the Washington continental shelf and slope contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 0.9-1.2, 1.6-2.8, 0.5-1.5 and <0.1-0.4 ug/g organic carbon; samples were from the inner shelf, midshelf, outer shelf and slope, respectively(3). Bed sediments collected along a contamination gradient in the Lauritzen Canal, CA in 1993 contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 150-1380 ng/g; the highest concentration occurring at the head of the canal(4). Bed and suspended sediment samples taken from Suisun Bay, CA contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 1.0-18 and not detected to 20 ng/g dry weight, respectively(5).

sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in surface sediment samples from the Saguenay Fjord, Quebec, Canada in Aug 1983(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 0.036 ug/g in one of eight sediments collected Aug 25-Sept 12 1985 and June 21-July 1, 1986 from the Mackenzie River, Canada(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was reported in sediment samples from Macaulay Point, Canada at 28-1800 ug/kg(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene/dibenzo(a,h)anthracene was detected in surface marine sediments George's River, Australia at 22-5172 ug/kg dry weight(4). Mean indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations in surface sediment samples from the Brisbane River estuary, Australia were 0.15-0.75 ug/g dry weight(5). It was also detected in particulates in water from the Brisbane River estuary at a mean of 0.06-0.12 ug/g dry weight(5). Sediment samples taken from the Hun, Taizi and Daliao rivers in China contained not detected to 119.66, not detected to 254.44 and not detected to 81.56 ng/g dry weight of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene, respectively; samples were collected Aug 2005(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 5.1-160.9 ng/g in sediment samples collected Sept 21, 2007 from Xiamen Bay, China(7). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 18-2320 ng/g dry weight in sediment samples collected Nov 2005 to Apr 2006 from 14 sites on the Shinano River, Japan(8).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bjoerseth A et al; Sci Total Environ 13: 71-86 (1979) (2) Sanders G et al; Chemosphere 12: 1567-82 (1993) (3) Domine D et al; Sci Total Environ 155: 9-24 (1994) (4) Villanueva J et al; Chemosphere 22: 317-26 (1991) (5) Hiller E wt al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 444-8 (2009) (6) Maranho LA et al; Ecotoxicology 24: 368-80 (2015)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations in sediment samples from Saudafjord, Norway were 7577.6, 6493.1, 5744.1 and 3077.6 ppb dry wt at respective depths of 0-2, 2-4, 4-6 and 6-8 cm(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in sediment layers from a rural English lake at concentrations of not detected to 4.49 ug/g dry weight; the highest concentration was detected in sediment layers representing 1965-1970, it was not detected in representative sediment layers prior to 1872(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 28 of 30 sediment samples collected from 15 sampling sites of the Mediterranean Sea and the Grand Rhone river at 0.2-323.3 ng/g dry weight(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in sediment core sections collected near an uncontrolled hazardous waste dump in North Spain at 2.1-100 ug/g(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at <2.00-85.72 and <2.00-129.80 ng/g in sediment samples collected in March and Sept 2011, respectively, from six sites in the Bay of Cadiz, Spain(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in sediment samples collected June 2005 from the Ruzin, Velke Kozmalovce and Zemplinska Sirava reservoirs in Slovakia at respective concentrations of 227-583, 194-282 and 6-71 ng/g dry weight(6).

SEDIMENT: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 12 surface sediment samples (0-2 cm depth) collected in 1988 from the Black Sea at 1-190 ng/g dry weight(1). Concentrations in a sediment core from the Euxine Abyssal Plain were as follows(1):

sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in coal tar contaminated soil from a site in Southern New Jersey at 36.4 ug/g(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in soil/waste samples from the Doepke-Holliday site in Johnson City, KS at 18,000 ug/kg(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in soil samples from an oil refinery in Washington state at 15, 6 and <0.5 mg/kg at respective soil depths of 0-6, 12-24 and 24-54 inches(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in soil samples collected July 21-23, 1992 from Boston and Springfield, MA, and Providence, RI at 0.093-6.00 mg/kg with an average of 0.987 mg/kg(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in coal tar-contaminated soil from a manufactured gas plant in New York at 32 ug/g(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in soil at 0.5 ug/g; sample was collected from a plastics company involved in a major fire in 1997 in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentration in dry months of 2008 was 0.56 ng/kg, and 1.24 and 0.53 ng/kg in wet months of 2009; samples were collected from crop lands in Mexico City, Mexico(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Sims RC, Overcash MR; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983) (2) Leeming R; Maher W; Org Geochem 18: 647-55 (1992) (3) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (4) Smith DJT et al; Environ Technol 16: 45-53 (1995) (5) Jones KC et al; Environ Sci Technol 23: 95-101 (1989) (6) Heywood E et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 7629-35 (2006) (7) Berset JD, Holzer R; Int J Environ Anal Chem 59: 145-65 (1995) (8) Maliszewska-Kordybach B et al; Sci Total Environ 407:3746-53 (2009) (9) Bixiong Y et al; Chemosphere 64:525-34 (2006) (10) Cai QY et al; Chemosphere 68 159-68 (2007) (11) Wang Z et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 1336-41 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in forest soil in Germany at 10-15 ppb(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in soil samples from Civic and Queanbean, Australia at 41 and 56 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(2). Soil and leaf litter samples collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 36 ng/g dry weight and 45 ng/g wet weight of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 155 ug/kg in soil samples collected in Birmingham, UK and at 584 ug/kg in soil samples from Brisbane, Australia(4). Archived soil samples from an agricultural experimental field in England had indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations of 23, 14, 5, 12, 31, 92, 29, 100 and 63 ng/g from soil samples corresponding to respective years sampled of 1846, 1881, 1893, 1914, 1944, 1956, 1966, 1980 and 1986(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 2.72-710 ng/g dry weight (mean and median; 84.3 and 34.9 ng/g dry weight) in 201 soil samples from 32 different land types collected from across Great Britain(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 20 soil samples from the Swiss Soil Monitoring Network at a range and mean concentration of 5-43 and 13.8 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(7). In 216 soil samples collected from agricultural fields in 2005 from Poland, indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at <6.6-85 ug/kg(8). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 188 top soil samples from the Tianjin, China at an approximate geometric mean of 0.06 ug/g; areas of sampling included farmland using wastewater irrigation, common farmland, mountainous are, wild land, oil field and city greenbelt(9). Surface soils from nine representative vegetable fields located in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Zengcheng and Huadu, China contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at not detected to 49 ug/kg; samples were collected the summer of 2002(10). In April 2005, soil samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China; indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 4-278 ng/g dry weight(11).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Garcia-Falcon MS et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 759-63 (2006)
